**Transcript**:
Perfumers can learn to distinguish
individual odors in a fragrance made of hundreds of scents. Tea experts have been known to sniff out not just the location 
where a tea was from, but the season of harvest
and whether it was planted by a plum tree. And the New York City Transit Authority once had an employee responsible
only for sniffing out gas leaks in the subway system. Can just anyone learn to smell
with the sensitivity of those experts? For most of us, what we smell
is largely involuntary, whether it's garbage behind a restaurant, the shampoo of the woman leaving
an elevator as you enter, or a bakery's fresh-made bread. With a few million olfactory receptors
in our noses, we clearly don't lack the ability
to smell well. We just might not always pay close
enough attention. That's a shame because we may be
missing opportunities to make strong emotional connections. Smells are powerfully linked to emotions and can awaken memories of places
we've long ago left and people we've loved. But fortunately, it is possible
to train our brains to smell better. For example, Helen Keller was able
to recognize a person's work, and in her words, distinguish the carpenter
from the iron worker, the artist from the mason or the chemist, by a simple inhale. Follow these steps and you too can
change the way the world smells to you. First, stick your nose in it. Some animals that are known
to be great smellers, like dogs who can sniff out explosives and pigs who can 
find truffles underground, put their noses right at the place
they want to smell. Human noses, meanwhile, are casting
around in the middle of the air, giving us an anatomical disadvantage. So bring your nose close to the world
around you. The ground, surfaces, objects, the food in your hand. Get close to your dog, your partner, the book you're reading. Not only will your nose be closer
to the odor source, but the warmth of your breath
will make odors easier to smell. Second, sniff like you mean it. Smelling actually happens way up near
the bridge of our noses in a postage stamp-sized square
of tissue called the olfactory epithelium. When we sniff, odor molecules are sucked
up into our nostrils until they hit this tissue where they combine to our olfactory,
or scent, receptors. When we inhale normally,
only a little air makes it there. But one or two solid sharp sniffs will ensure that more air gets to
your smell receptors. After just a few more sniffs, the receptors, which are best at
noticing new smells, turn off temporarily. So you can give your nose a rest
and sniff again later. Finally, dwell on the smell. Most smells pass by us 
with little attention, but simply noticing what you're smelling and by trying to describe it, name it,
and locate its source, you can expand your vocabulary of smells. When an odor molecule binds
to a scent receptor, it sends an electrical signal
from the sensory neurons to our brain's olfactory bulbs. The signal then continues to other
areas of the brain, where it's integrated with taste, memory, or emotional information before registering to us as a smell. FMRI research shows that the extra
time spent focusing on scent changes the brain of experienced smellers. For them, perceiving and imagining odors
becomes more automatic than for non-experts. To get started yourself, take ingredients
from your kitchen: spices, vanilla, or fruit, but never anything toxic. Close your eyes and have someone
bring them under your nose. Sniff and try to name the source. Over time, you'll begin to appreciate
nuances in familiar odors and recognize characteristics of new
and unusual smells. The perfumer has practiced these steps
enough to become an artist of odor, but even if you never pursue smelling
to that degree, the spectacular result 
of an unspectacular action will change how you sense 
and experience your days.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why should you give a good, long sniff to something you would like to smell?
Options: A. More odor molecules will be taken in, resulting in better smell detection, B. In humans, the tissue that helps us smell is located high up in the nasal cavity, C. The olfactory epithelium is a small patch of cells, D. B and C, E. All of the above
Correct Option: E

individual odors in a fragrance made of hundreds of scents. Tea experts have been known to sniff out not just the location 
where a tea was from, but the season of harvest
and whether it was planted by a plum tree. And the New York City Transit Authority once had an employee responsible

an elevator as you enter, or a bakery's fresh-made bread. With a few million olfactory receptors

enough attention. That's a shame because we may be

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Olfactory receptors:
Options: A. Detect new smells best, B. Detect familiar odors best, C. Never shut off, D. Are found near the tip of your nose
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was a notable difference in car designs between the 1970s and 1990s? Options: A. Cars from the 1970s were smaller than those from the 1990s., B. Cars from the 1970s were boxy, while those from the 1990s were curvy., C. Cars from the 1970s were more fuel-efficient than those from the 1990s., D. Cars from the 1970s were more expensive than those from the 1990s. Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which car model is credited with being the first to popularize the curved design for the average driver? Options: A. Ford Sierra, B. Ford Taurus, C. Buick LeSabre, D. Chrysler Airflow Correct Option: A
Question 3: What was the nickname given to the Ford Sierra due to its unique design? Options: A. "The Jelly Mould", B. "The Streamliner", C. "The Aerodynamic", D. "The Curvy Car" Correct Option: A
Question 4: Why did American automakers start to copy the European aerodynamic look? Options: A. To improve fuel efficiency, B. To reduce production costs, C. To increase market share, D. To attract more upscale consumers Correct Option: D
Question 5: How did the rise of computer modelling in the 1980s affect car design? Options: A. It made it more difficult to design and manufacture curved lines, B. It had no impact on car design, C. It made it easier to design and manufacture curved lines, D. It led to a decrease in fuel efficiency Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the result of the Ford Taurus's design breakthrough? Options: A. It led to a decrease in sales, B. It inspired a wave of copycat curvy cars, C. It led to an increase in production costs, D. It had no impact on the market Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the primary reason for the increase in aerodynamic design in the 1980s? Options: A. To improve fuel efficiency, B. To reduce production costs, C. To increase market share, D. To attract more upscale consumers Correct Option: A
Question 8: How did the European designers' approach to car design differ from the American approach in the 1960s? Options: A. European designers focused on aerodynamics, while American designers focused on size and power, B. European designers focused on size and power, while American designers focused on aerodynamics, C. European designers focused on comfort and luxury, while American designers focused on performance and style, D. European designers focused on performance and style, while American designers focused on comfort and luxury Correct Option: A
Question 9: What was the impact of the Ford Taurus's design on the automotive industry? Options: A. It led to a decrease in sales for other car manufacturers, B. It inspired a wave of copycat curvy cars, C. It led to an increase in production costs for other car manufacturers, D. It had no impact on the market Correct Option: B
Question 10: What factors contributed to the shift towards more aerodynamic car designs in the 1980s? Options: A. Rising gas prices, increased fuel economy regulations, and the rise of computer modelling, B. Decreasing gas prices, decreased fuel economy regulations, and the decline of computer modelling, C. Decreasing gas prices, increased fuel economy regulations, and the decline of computer modelling, D. Decreasing gas prices, decreased fuel economy regulations, and the rise of computer modelling Correct Option: A
Question 11: What was the significance of the 1986 Ford Taurus in the automotive industry? Options: A. It was the first mass-market car with a curvy design, B. It was the first car to use aerodynamic design for fuel efficiency, C. It was the first car to use computer-aided design, D. It was the first car to use wind tunnel testing Correct Option: A
Question 12: Who was the designer responsible for bringing wind tunnel testing into the Ford design process? Options: A. Jack Telnack, B. Uwe Bahnsen, C. Henry Ford, D. Lee Iacocca Correct Option: A
Question 13: What was the primary reason for the decline of American streamliners in the 1950s and 1960s? Options: A. Gas prices were on fairly steady decline, so streamlining for fuel efficiency was less of a concern, B. European designers focused on aerodynamics, while American designers focused on size and power, C. American consumers preferred boxy cars, D. The US government imposed regulations on car design Correct Option: A
Question 14: What was the nickname given to the Buick LeSabre due to its design change in the 1990s? Options: A. "The Jelly Mould", B. "The Streamliner", C. "The Aerodynamic", D. "The Curvy Car" Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you look at cars from the 1970s and cars
from the 1990s, there’s really one big difference in their designs. The ones from the 70s are boxy, and the ones
from the 90s are curvy. For some car models, you can even tell the
exact year when that change happened. Just look at this commercial for the Buick
LeSabre, showing the 1991 model — and then the 1992 model. See the curves? Let’s watch that again. ‘91 is boxy, sharp edges. ‘92? Smooth and round. Since then, cars have become curvier and curvier. So how did this happen? When manufacturers started making curvy cars
in the 90s, it wasn’t a totally new concept. Back in the 1930s, streamliners like this Chrysler
Airflow used this sleek design to reduce wind resistance. But as the 50s and 60s rolled around, American
streamliners stopped selling well — they were outsold by bigger, boxier cars. Gas prices were on fairly steady decline at
this point, so streamlining for fuel efficiency was less of a concern. Well into the 1970s, just about every car
made in America had sharp edges and very few curves. They were basically designed as a series of
three boxes — the hood, the cabin, and the trunk. That model worked really well in the US market. But in Europe, fuel was always more expensive. In the 60s, a gallon of gas in France cost
a whopping 73.1 cents while it was just 31 cents in the US. So European designers started experimenting
with more aerodynamic designs to help cars move more easily so they’d waste less gas. Automakers like Porsche, BMW, Audi, Mercedes-Benz
— they all started rolling out car models that had curved exteriors. Eventually American automakers started to
copy the European aerodynamic look to try to attract upscale consumers. The mass market was a different picture. In Europe, a designer named Uwe Bahnsen was
the first person to push for a curved design for the average driver, and he did that with
the 1982 Ford Sierra. It was curvier than any car in its class at
the time. But critics just laughed at it. And it didn't sell very well at first. It was nicknamed the “jelly mould” because
of how much it looked like the kind of circular shape you’d make JELL-O with. But one of the designers from that European
Ford design team — this guy, Jack Telnack — took over the US design team in 1980. American gas prices at this point were skyrocketing
due to conflict in the middle east. So Telnack brought wind tunnel testing into
the design process. He first did that with the 1983 Ford Thunderbird. But the real breakthrough came a few years
later: "The result was the groundbreaking 1986 Ford
Taurus." It might not look that groundbreaking now,
but this style was revolutionary at the time. It was a mass market car with curvy edges
— and people liked it. “Taurus! Now a North American car with a shape and
a feel we’ve never seen before… Taurus for us!” They used it in RoboCop as the car of the
future. The sales basically saved Ford, which had
really been struggling at the time, and it inspired a whole wave of copycat curvy cars. And streamlining became even more popular
because manufacturers were facing new fuel economy regulations in the US. Starting in 1978, the average fuel efficiency
of each manufacturer’s passenger cars had to meet higher and higher levels. According to one Ford designer, aerodynamic
design was a much more affordable way to boost efficiency than doing engineering work under
the hood. The rise of computer modelling in the 80s
also made it easier for car makers to design and manufacture curved lines. All these years later, the influence on today’s
cars is pretty clear. Even the models that we criticize for being
ridiculously boxy these days — like the Scion xB — are actually really round. And if our modern day sci fi movies have anything
to say about it, that won’t be changing anytime soon.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: According to this video, what was the main reason cars went from being 'curvy' to 'boxy' in the early 1960s?
Options: A. curvy cars were considered 'un-American', B. America was in a race to land on the moon, and boxy cars were considered futuristic, C. fuel prices were dropping
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the initial idea of the speaker's first-grade teacher? Options: A. To have the students participate in a science experiment., B. To have the students receive gifts and compliment each other., C. To have the students learn a new language., D. To have the students work together to build a team. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the speaker's initial reaction when they were rejected by the security guard at work? Options: A. They felt a sense of accomplishment and confidence., B. They felt embarrassed and ran away., C. They felt angry and wanted to argue with the guard., D. They felt sad and wanted to give up. Correct Option: B
Question 3: What did the speaker learn from their experience of asking the manager at Krispy Kreme to make Olympic-themed doughnuts? Options: A. That they should never take rejection personally., B. That they can turn a "no" into a "yes" by asking "why"., C. That they should always be prepared for rejection., D. That they should never try new things. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the speaker's goal for their 100 days of rejection? Options: A. To become famous and wealthy., B. To start their own business., C. To teach others how to overcome their fear of rejection., D. To learn how to overcome their fear of rejection. Correct Option: D
Question 5: What did the speaker discover about how to maximize their chance of getting a "yes"? Options: A. That they should always be confident and assertive., B. That they should mention some doubt people might have before asking the question., C. That they should never ask questions., D. That they should always be prepared to negotiate. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What was the speaker's dream to fulfill, and how did they achieve it? Options: A. To become a famous entrepreneur, and they achieved it by starting their own business., B. To teach something, and they achieved it by asking and teaching a college class., C. To become a successful author, and they achieved it by writing a book., D. To become a famous artist, and they achieved it by creating a painting. Correct Option: B
Question 7: Who are some examples of people who were met with initial and often violent rejections, but still changed the world? Options: A. Martin Luther King, Jr., Mahatma Gandhi, Nelson Mandela, and Jesus Christ., B. Albert Einstein, Marie Curie, and Charles Darwin., C. Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, and Raphael., D. William Shakespeare, Jane Austen, and Charles Dickens. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What was the speaker's initial reaction to rejection, and how did it change over time? Options: A. They initially felt confident and prepared for rejection, but later became fearful and ran away from it., B. They initially felt fearful and ran away from rejection, but later learned to embrace it., C. They initially felt angry and wanted to argue with people who rejected them, but later became more understanding., D. They initially felt sad and wanted to give up, but later became more motivated. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the main idea of the speaker's book? Options: A. How to become a successful entrepreneur., B. How to overcome the fear of rejection and turn it into opportunities., C. How to become a famous artist., D. How to become a successful author. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the speaker's current goal, and how is he working towards it? Options: A. To become a famous entrepreneur, and he is working towards it by starting his own business., B. To teach others how to overcome their fear of rejection, and he is working towards it by writing a book, giving talks, and building technology., C. To become a successful author, and he is working towards it by writing a book., D. To become a famous artist, and he is working towards it by creating a painting. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the question format and style, I would say that none of the generated MCQs are similar to the ground truth MCQ.

**Transcript**:
If you look at cars from the 1970s and cars
from the 1990s, there’s really one big difference in their designs. The ones from the 70s are boxy, and the ones
from the 90s are curvy. For some car models, you can even tell the
exact year when that change happened. Just look at this commercial for the Buick

Airflow used this sleek design to reduce wind resistance. But as the 50s and 60s rolled around, American

ridiculously boxy these days — like the Scion xB — are actually really round. And if our modern day sci fi movies have anything
to say about it, that won’t be changing anytime soon.

Options: A. because they were considered "European", B. because manufacturing curves was more expensive
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Some of the world's most recognizable
symbols exist to sell products, others to steer traffic or advance political causes. But there's one whose main purpose
is to help people. You may know it as the wheelchair symbol,
or a sign for people with disabilities, but its formal title as maintained
by the ISO is the International Symbol of Access. But despite its familiarity, many people are unclear as to what 
the symbol actually means, which has a lot to do with the symbol
itself and the way it came about. In 1968, the International Commission
on Technology and Accessibility held a design contest. They were looking for a symbol that would be readily identifiable 
from a reasonable distance, self-descriptive, simple, practical, and couldn't be confused
with existing signage. The winning design, 
which didn't have a head, was created by a Danish designer
named Susanne Koefed. The addition of a head a year later
gave it a more human form, and within ten years, it was endorsed by both the United Nations
and the ISO. With minimal cost and minimal fuss,
a global icon was born. There have been a few tweaks
over the decades. The Graphic Artists Guild added more
rounded, human-like features, and in 2012, the Accessible Icon Project
produced a more dynamic version. But what does it really represent? What's its purpose? Put simply, it's a sign to identify where
there are accessible facilities. The strength of such an internationally
recognized image is that wherever you travel, you don't need to speak the language
or have in-depth cultural knowledge. If you require an accessible toilet,
the sign shows the way. But the confusion comes 
from the term accessibility and what that actually means. Many people assume that because
the symbol depicts a wheelchair, that accessible facilities are meant
only for people who use wheelchairs, or those, at the very least,
who have a visible physical condition. But accessibility is a broad concept that applies to many, 
many different conditions. That includes people with autism, visual impairments, and autoimmune diseases, like lupus, which can cause 
pain and fatigue, along with many other conditions. In fact, the World Health 
Organization estimates that there are approximately
1 billion people who experience some form of disability, which means that this group is very
likely to include yourself, or a family member, a classmate, a friend, or a work colleague. And people who use wheelchairs only
make up about 65 million, or 15% of the total. The vast majority 
have non-visible disabilities. Accessible parking spaces, facilities,
and entrances are designed with 
that entire group in mind. So it's easy to see why in recent years
people have begun to raise questions about whether the symbol is really
appropriate for what it's meant to do. And it's not just about accuracy. It's common for people 
to become indignant, sometimes abusive, when they see people without visible
disabilities using accessible facilities. The symbol is unfortunately creating
widespread issues for the very people and families
it's meant to help. The recent redesigns have attempted
with some success to acknowledge concerns 
over the current symbol. But some think that a complete redesign
is in order. It's a difficult task, though. How do you replace a symbol 
that's familiar the world over? And what do you replace it with?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was missing from the original design of the International Symbol of Access?
Options: A. A wheel, B. A head, C. A person, D. A leg
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is the 35-year-old doctor in the transcript? Options: A. Louis Pasteur, B. René Laennec, C. Florence Nightingale, D. Ignaz Semmelweis Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the inspiration behind René Laennec's invention of the stethoscope? Options: A. He observed two children playing with a piece of string, B. He saw a group of musicians using a wooden board to amplify sound, C. He remembered watching two children signal to each other using a long piece of wooden board, D. He read about a similar device in an ancient medical text Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was René Laennec's initial hesitation when assessing the young woman with a heart condition? Options: A. He was concerned about the patient's age, B. He was worried about the patient's weight, C. He was hesitant to press his ear directly against her chest, D. He was unsure about the patient's symptoms Correct Option: C
Question 4: What material did René Laennec initially use to develop his stethoscope? Options: A. Metal, B. Plastic, C. Rubber, D. A hollow wooden tube Correct Option: D
Question 5: How many years did René Laennec spend developing and testing his stethoscope? Options: A. 1 year, B. 2 years, C. 3 years, D. 5 years Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the outcome of René Laennec's invention of the stethoscope? Options: A. It became a rare medical tool, B. It was used only in hospitals, C. It became the forerunner to modern stethoscopes, D. It was not widely accepted by the medical community Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the primary function of a stethoscope? Options: A. To diagnose diseases, B. To monitor vital signs, C. To amplify sound, D. To take blood pressure readings Correct Option: C
Question 8: What can be inferred about René Laennec's character from the transcript? Options: A. He was hesitant and unsure of himself, B. He was quick to act without thinking, C. He was a man of dignity and vision, D. He was not interested in innovation Correct Option: C
Question 9: How did René Laennec's invention of the stethoscope impact the medical field? Options: A. It led to a decrease in the number of medical students, B. It made it easier for doctors to diagnose diseases, C. It led to a decrease in the number of medical discoveries, D. It had no impact on the medical field Correct Option: B
Question 10: What can be learned from René Laennec's experience of developing the stethoscope? Options: A. The importance of being quick to act without thinking, B. The value of perseverance and dedication, C. The need to be hesitant and unsure of oneself, D. The importance of ignoring inspiration and intuition Correct Option: B
Question 11: What was the purpose of the children's wooden board in the transcript? Options: A. To demonstrate a musical instrument, B. To show a method of communication, C. To amplify sound, D. To create a makeshift bridge Correct Option: C
Question 12: How did René Laennec's invention of the stethoscope improve medical practice? Options: A. It allowed doctors to perform surgeries more easily, B. It enabled doctors to take blood pressure readings more accurately, C. It allowed doctors to listen to the sounds of the body more clearly, D. It had no impact on medical practice Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. The generated MCQs appear to be related to a different topic, specifically the invention of the stethoscope by René Laennec.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the format and structure of the question, I would say that Question 4 is the closest match. **Transcript**:

symbols exist to sell products, others to steer traffic or advance political causes. But there's one whose main purpose

the symbol depicts a wheelchair, that accessible facilities are meant
only for people who use wheelchairs, or those, at the very least,
who have a visible physical condition. But accessibility is a broad concept that applies to many, 
many different conditions. That includes people with autism, visual impairments, and autoimmune diseases, like lupus, which can cause 
pain and fatigue, along with many other conditions. In fact, the World Health 
Organization estimates that there are approximately
1 billion people who experience some form of disability, which means that this group is very
likely to include yourself, or a family member, a classmate, a friend, or a work colleague. And people who use wheelchairs only
make up about 65 million, or 15% of the total. The vast majority 
have non-visible disabilities. Accessible parking spaces, facilities,
and entrances are designed with 
that entire group in mind. So it's easy to see why in recent years
people have begun to raise questions about whether the symbol is really
appropriate for what it's meant to do. And it's not just about accuracy. It's common for people 
to become indignant, sometimes abusive, when they see people without visible
disabilities using accessible facilities. The symbol is unfortunately creating
widespread issues for the very people and families
it's meant to help. The recent redesigns have attempted
with some success to acknowledge concerns 
over the current symbol. But some think that a complete redesign
is in order. It's a difficult task, though. How do you replace a symbol 
that's familiar the world over? And what do you replace it with?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many people across the globe does the World Health Organization estimate are living with some type of disability?
Options: A. One hundred thousand, B. One million, C. Fifty million, D. One billion
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is the 35-year-old doctor in the transcript? Options: A. Louis Pasteur, B. René Laennec, C. Florence Nightingale, D. Ignaz Semmelweis Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the inspiration behind René Laennec's invention of the stethoscope? Options: A. He observed two children playing with a piece of string, B. He saw a group of musicians using a wooden board to amplify sound, C. He remembered watching two children signal to each other using a long piece of wooden board, D. He read about a similar device in an ancient medical text Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was René Laennec's initial hesitation when assessing the young woman with a heart condition? Options: A. He was concerned about the patient's age, B. He was worried about the patient's weight, C. He was hesitant to press his ear directly against her chest, D. He was unsure about the patient's symptoms Correct Option: C
Question 4: What material did René Laennec initially use to develop his stethoscope? Options: A. Metal, B. Plastic, C. Rubber, D. A hollow wooden tube Correct Option: D
Question 5: How many years did René Laennec spend developing and testing his stethoscope? Options: A. 1 year, B. 2 years, C. 3 years, D. 5 years Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the outcome of René Laennec's invention of the stethoscope? Options: A. It became a rare medical tool, B. It was used only in hospitals, C. It became the forerunner to modern stethoscopes, D. It was not widely accepted by the medical community Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the primary function of a stethoscope? Options: A. To diagnose diseases, B. To monitor vital signs, C. To amplify sound, D. To take blood pressure readings Correct Option: C
Question 8: What can be inferred about René Laennec's character from the transcript? Options: A. He was hesitant and unsure of himself, B. He was quick to act without thinking, C. He was a man of dignity and vision, D. He was not interested in innovation Correct Option: C
Question 9: How did René Laennec's invention of the stethoscope impact the medical field? Options: A. It led to a decrease in the number of medical students, B. It made it easier for doctors to diagnose diseases, C. It led to a decrease in the number of medical discoveries, D. It had no impact on the medical field Correct Option: B
Question 10: What can be learned from René Laennec's experience of developing the stethoscope? Options: A. The importance of being quick to act without thinking, B. The value of perseverance and dedication, C. The need to be hesitant and unsure of oneself, D. The importance of ignoring inspiration and intuition Correct Option: B
Question 11: What was the purpose of the children's wooden board in the transcript? Options: A. To demonstrate a musical instrument, B. To show a method of communication, C. To amplify sound, D. To create a makeshift bridge Correct Option: C
Question 12: How did René Laennec's invention of the stethoscope improve medical practice? Options: A. It allowed doctors to perform surgeries more easily, B. It enabled doctors to take blood pressure readings more accurately, C. It allowed doctors to listen to the sounds of the body more clearly, D. It had no impact on medical practice Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Some of the world's most recognizable
symbols exist to sell products, others to steer traffic or advance political causes. But there's one whose main purpose
is to help people. You may know it as the wheelchair symbol,
or a sign for people with disabilities, but its formal title as maintained
by the ISO is the International Symbol of Access. But despite its familiarity, many people are unclear as to what 
the symbol actually means, which has a lot to do with the symbol
itself and the way it came about. In 1968, the International Commission
on Technology and Accessibility held a design contest. They were looking for a symbol that would be readily identifiable 
from a reasonable distance, self-descriptive, simple, practical, and couldn't be confused
with existing signage. The winning design, 
which didn't have a head, was created by a Danish designer
named Susanne Koefed. The addition of a head a year later
gave it a more human form, and within ten years, it was endorsed by both the United Nations
and the ISO. With minimal cost and minimal fuss,
a global icon was born. There have been a few tweaks
over the decades. The Graphic Artists Guild added more
rounded, human-like features, and in 2012, the Accessible Icon Project
produced a more dynamic version. But what does it really represent? What's its purpose? Put simply, it's a sign to identify where
there are accessible facilities. The strength of such an internationally
recognized image is that wherever you travel, you don't need to speak the language
or have in-depth cultural knowledge. If you require an accessible toilet,
the sign shows the way. But the confusion comes 
from the term accessibility and what that actually means. Many people assume that because
the symbol depicts a wheelchair, that accessible facilities are meant
only for people who use wheelchairs, or those, at the very least,
who have a visible physical condition. But accessibility is a broad concept that applies to many, 
many different conditions. That includes people with autism, visual impairments, and autoimmune diseases, like lupus, which can cause 
pain and fatigue, along with many other conditions. In fact, the World Health 
Organization estimates that there are approximately
1 billion people who experience some form of disability, which means that this group is very
likely to include yourself, or a family member, a classmate, a friend, or a work colleague. And people who use wheelchairs only
make up about 65 million, or 15% of the total. The vast majority 
have non-visible disabilities. Accessible parking spaces, facilities,
and entrances are designed with 
that entire group in mind. So it's easy to see why in recent years
people have begun to raise questions about whether the symbol is really
appropriate for what it's meant to do. And it's not just about accuracy. It's common for people 
to become indignant, sometimes abusive, when they see people without visible
disabilities using accessible facilities. The symbol is unfortunately creating
widespread issues for the very people and families
it's meant to help. The recent redesigns have attempted
with some success to acknowledge concerns 
over the current symbol. But some think that a complete redesign
is in order. It's a difficult task, though. How do you replace a symbol 
that's familiar the world over? And what do you replace it with?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What does the acronym ISO stand for?
Options: A. International Signage Organization, B. International Organization for Standardization, C. Ideal Symbol Organization, D. Interesting Symbol Organization
Correct Option: B

It made it easier for doctors to diagnose diseases, C. It led to a decrease in the number of medical discoveries, D. It had no impact on the medical field Correct Option: B

The value of perseverance and dedication, C. The need to be hesitant and unsure of oneself, D. The importance of ignoring inspiration and intuition Correct Option: B

It enabled doctors to take blood pressure readings more accurately, C. It allowed doctors to listen to the sounds of the body more clearly, D. It had no impact on medical practice Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
You’re the realm’s greatest mathematician, but ever since you criticized
the emperor's tax laws, you’ve been locked in the dungeon 
with only a marker to count the days. But one day you're suddenly brought
before the emperor, who looks even angrier than usual. One of his 12 governors has been convicted
of paying his taxes with a counterfeit coin, which has already made its way 
into the Treasury. As the kingdom's greatest mathematician, you’ve been granted a chance to earn 
your freedom by identifying the fake. Before you are the 12 identical looking
coins and a balance scale. You know that the false coin will be very
slightly lighter or heavier than the rest. But the emperor’s not a patient man. You may only use the scale three times before you’ll be thrown 
back into the dungeon. You look around for
anything else you can use, but there's nothing in the room,
just the coins, the scale, and your trusty marker. How do you identify the counterfeit? Pause now to figure it out yourself! Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 Obviously, you can't weigh each coin
against all of the others, so you’ll have to weigh several coins
at the same time by splitting the stack 
into multiple piles, then narrowing down where
the false coin is. Start by dividing the 12 coins 
into three equal piles of four. Placing two of these on the scale
gives us two possible outcomes. If the two sides balance, 
all eight coins on the scale are real and the fake must be among 
the remaining four. So how do you keep track of these results?
That’s where the marker comes in. Mark the eight authentic
coins with a zero. Now take three of them and weigh them
against three unmarked coins. If they balance, the remaining unmarked
coin must be the fake. If they don’t, draw a plus 
on the three unmarked coins if they’re heavier, 
or a minus if they’re lighter. Now take two of the newly marked coins
and weigh them against each other. If they balance, the third coin is fake. Otherwise, look at their marks. If they are plus coins, 
the heavier one is the impostor. If they are marked with minus,
it's the lighter one. But what if the first two piles
you way don't balance? Mark the coins on the heavier side
with a plus and those on the lighter side 
with a minus. You can also mark the remaining four
coins with zeros, since you know the fake one 
is already somewhere on the scale. Now you'll need to think strategically so you can remove all remaining ambiguity
in just two more ways. To do this, you’ll need 
to reassemble the piles. One method is to replace three 
of the plus coins with three of the minus coins and replace those
with three of the zero coins. From here, you have three possibilities. If the previously heavier side 
of the scale is still heavier, that means either the remaining 
plus coin on that side is actually the heavier one, or the remaining minus coin on the 
lighter side is actually the lighter one. Choose either one of them and weigh it 
against one of the regular coins to see which is true. If the previously heavier side 
became lighter, that means one of the three minus coins
you moved is actually the lighter one. Weigh two of them against each other. If they balance, the third is counterfeit. If not, the lighter one is. Similarly, if the two sides balanced
after your substitution, then one of the three plus coins 
you removed must be the heavier one. Weigh two of them against each other. If they balance, the third one is fake. If not, then it's the heavier one. The emperor nods approvingly
at your finding, and the counterfeiting lord 
takes your place in the dungeon.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: If you know that among four otherwise identical coins one is heavier than the others, what is the minimum number of weighs you would need to uncover the single counterfeit coin?
Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 3, D. 4
Correct Option: B

Question 1: What is the origin of the festive Christmas tradition of kissing under mistletoe? Options: A. Ancient Roman mythology, B. Scandinavian legends, C. European folklore, D. The tradition of kissing under mistletoe originated from a combination of European folklore and the myth of Baldur in Scandinavian legends Correct Option: D
Question 2: What did the Druid priesthood in ancient England believe about mistletoe? Options: A. It was a poisonous plant, B. It was a symbol of death, C. It was a plant dropped down from heaven by the gods, D. It had powers of healing and bestowing fertility Correct Option: D
Question 3: What is the unique relationship between mistletoe and trees? Options: A. Mistletoe relies on trees for shade and protection, B. Mistletoe grows on trees as an epiphyte, C. Mistletoe is a partly parasitic plant that penetrates tree bark with modified roots called haustoria, D. Mistletoe is a type of tree that grows in dense forests Correct Option: C
Question 4: How do birds contribute to the dispersal of mistletoe seeds? Options: A. Birds eat the seeds and store them in their stomachs, B. Birds excrete the seeds onto tree bark or other surfaces, often in a sticky white berry that can germinate and start to grow, C. Birds dig holes for the seeds to germinate, D. Birds do not play a role in the dispersal of mistletoe seeds Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the significance of mistletoe in supporting biodiversity? Options: A. Mistletoe is a keystone species that supports a variety of animals, including birds, squirrels, and deer, B. Mistletoe is a food source for only a few species, C. Mistletoe is a competitor to other plants for resources, D. Mistletoe has no impact on biodiversity Correct Option: A
Question 6: How do juniper sprouts benefit from mistletoe? Options: A. Juniper sprouts compete with mistletoe for resources, B. Juniper sprouts provide a habitat for mistletoe, C. Juniper sprouts benefit from visiting berry-eating birds that also eat mistletoe, creating a symbiotic relationship, D. Juniper sprouts are a food source for mistletoe Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the origin of the Christmas tradition of hanging mistletoe in Britain? Options: A. It was brought to Britain by British colonists in the New World, B. It was a European tradition that was adopted in Britain, C. It was a British tradition that was adopted in Europe, D. It was a Scandinavian tradition that was adopted in Britain Correct Option: B
Question 8: What do the pearly berries on mistletoe represent? Options: A. They are a sign of the plant's magical qualities, B. They are a sign of the plant's fertility, C. They are a symbol of love, peace, and unity, representing the plant's ability to bring people together, D. They are a sign of the plant's ability to heal Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the significance of mistletoe in the myth of Baldur? Options: A. Mistletoe is a symbol of death in the myth of Baldur, B. Mistletoe is a symbol of love and fertility in the myth of Baldur, representing the transformation of the plant from a symbol of death to one of peace and love, C. Mistletoe is a symbol of Baldur's resurrection, D. Mistletoe has no connection to the myth of Baldur Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the significance of mistletoe in modern times? Options: A. It is a rare and endangered plant species, B. It is a highly invasive plant species, C. It is a keystone species that supports biodiversity and has cultural and symbolic significance, D. It has no significance in modern times Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
You’re the realm’s greatest mathematician, but ever since you criticized
the emperor's tax laws, you’ve been locked in the dungeon 
with only a marker to count the days. But one day you're suddenly brought
before the emperor, who looks even angrier than usual. One of his 12 governors has been convicted
of paying his taxes with a counterfeit coin, which has already made its way 
into the Treasury. As the kingdom's greatest mathematician, you’ve been granted a chance to earn 
your freedom by identifying the fake. Before you are the 12 identical looking
coins and a balance scale. You know that the false coin will be very
slightly lighter or heavier than the rest. But the emperor’s not a patient man. You may only use the scale three times before you’ll be thrown 
back into the dungeon. You look around for
anything else you can use, but there's nothing in the room,
just the coins, the scale, and your trusty marker. How do you identify the counterfeit? Pause now to figure it out yourself! Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 Obviously, you can't weigh each coin
against all of the others, so you’ll have to weigh several coins
at the same time by splitting the stack 
into multiple piles, then narrowing down where
the false coin is. Start by dividing the 12 coins 
into three equal piles of four. Placing two of these on the scale
gives us two possible outcomes. If the two sides balance, 
all eight coins on the scale are real and the fake must be among 
the remaining four. So how do you keep track of these results?
That’s where the marker comes in. Mark the eight authentic
coins with a zero. Now take three of them and weigh them
against three unmarked coins. If they balance, the remaining unmarked
coin must be the fake. If they don’t, draw a plus 
on the three unmarked coins if they’re heavier, 
or a minus if they’re lighter. Now take two of the newly marked coins
and weigh them against each other. If they balance, the third coin is fake. Otherwise, look at their marks. If they are plus coins, 
the heavier one is the impostor. If they are marked with minus,
it's the lighter one. But what if the first two piles
you way don't balance? Mark the coins on the heavier side
with a plus and those on the lighter side 
with a minus. You can also mark the remaining four
coins with zeros, since you know the fake one 
is already somewhere on the scale. Now you'll need to think strategically so you can remove all remaining ambiguity
in just two more ways. To do this, you’ll need 
to reassemble the piles. One method is to replace three 
of the plus coins with three of the minus coins and replace those
with three of the zero coins. From here, you have three possibilities. If the previously heavier side 
of the scale is still heavier, that means either the remaining 
plus coin on that side is actually the heavier one, or the remaining minus coin on the 
lighter side is actually the lighter one. Choose either one of them and weigh it 
against one of the regular coins to see which is true. If the previously heavier side 
became lighter, that means one of the three minus coins
you moved is actually the lighter one. Weigh two of them against each other. If they balance, the third is counterfeit. If not, the lighter one is. Similarly, if the two sides balanced
after your substitution, then one of the three plus coins 
you removed must be the heavier one. Weigh two of them against each other. If they balance, the third one is fake. If not, then it's the heavier one. The emperor nods approvingly
at your finding, and the counterfeiting lord 
takes your place in the dungeon.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: If you know the single counterfeit coin is heavier than the others, what is the maximum number of coins for which one weighing is guaranteed to reveal the counterfeit?
Options: A. 2, B. 3, C. 4, D. 5
Correct Option: B

Correct Option: D

gives us two possible outcomes. If the two sides balance, 
all eight coins on the scale are real and the fake must be among 
the remaining four. So how do you keep track of these results?
That’s where the marker comes in. Mark the eight authentic
coins with a zero. Now take three of them and weigh them
against three unmarked coins. If they balance, the remaining unmarked
coin must be the fake. If they don’t, draw a plus 
on the three unmarked coins if they’re heavier, 
or a minus if they’re lighter. Now take two of the newly marked coins
and weigh them against each other. If they balance, the third coin is fake. Otherwise, look at their marks. If they are plus coins, 
the heavier one is the impostor. If they are marked with minus,
it's the lighter one. But what if the first two piles
you way don't balance? Mark the coins on the heavier side
with a plus and those on the lighter side 
with a minus. You can also mark the remaining four
coins with zeros, since you know the fake one 
is already somewhere on the scale. Now you'll need to think strategically so you can remove all remaining ambiguity
in just two more ways. To do this, you’ll need 
to reassemble the piles. One method is to replace three 
of the plus coins with three of the minus coins and replace those
with three of the zero coins. From here, you have three possibilities. If the previously heavier side 
of the scale is still heavier, that means either the remaining 
plus coin on that side is actually the heavier one, or the remaining minus coin on the 
lighter side is actually the lighter one. Choose either one of them and weigh it 
against one of the regular coins to see which is true. If the previously heavier side 
became lighter, that means one of the three minus coins
you moved is actually the lighter one. Weigh two of them against each other. If they balance, the third is counterfeit. If not, the lighter one is. Similarly, if the two sides balanced
after your substitution, then one of the three plus coins 
you removed must be the heavier one. Weigh two of them against each other. If they balance, the third one is fake. If not, then it's the heavier one. The emperor nods approvingly
at your finding, and the counterfeiting lord 
takes your place in the dungeon.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: If you don’t know whether the counterfeit coin is heavier or lighter, what is the maximum number of coins for which three weighs are guaranteed to uncover the single counterfeit coin AND determine its relative weight?
Options: A. 12, B. 13, C. 14, D. 15
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the origin of the festive Christmas tradition of kissing under mistletoe? Options: A. Ancient Roman mythology, B. Scandinavian legends, C. European folklore, D. The tradition of kissing under mistletoe originated from a combination of European folklore and the myth of Baldur in Scandinavian legends Correct Option: D
Question 2: What did the Druid priesthood in ancient England believe about mistletoe? Options: A. It was a poisonous plant, B. It was a symbol of death, C. It was a plant dropped down from heaven by the gods, D. It had powers of healing and bestowing fertility Correct Option: D
Question 3: What is the unique relationship between mistletoe and trees? Options: A. Mistletoe relies on trees for shade and protection, B. Mistletoe grows on trees as an epiphyte, C. Mistletoe is a partly parasitic plant that penetrates tree bark with modified roots called haustoria, D. Mistletoe is a type of tree that grows in dense forests Correct Option: C
Question 4: How do birds contribute to the dispersal of mistletoe seeds? Options: A. Birds eat the seeds and store them in their stomachs, B. Birds excrete the seeds onto tree bark or other surfaces, often in a sticky white berry that can germinate and start to grow, C. Birds dig holes for the seeds to germinate, D. Birds do not play a role in the dispersal of mistletoe seeds Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the significance of mistletoe in supporting biodiversity? Options: A. Mistletoe is a keystone species that supports a variety of animals, including birds, squirrels, and deer, B. Mistletoe is a food source for only a few species, C. Mistletoe is a competitor to other plants for resources, D. Mistletoe has no impact on biodiversity Correct Option: A
Question 6: How do juniper sprouts benefit from mistletoe? Options: A. Juniper sprouts compete with mistletoe for resources, B. Juniper sprouts provide a habitat for mistletoe, C. Juniper sprouts benefit from visiting berry-eating birds that also eat mistletoe, creating a symbiotic relationship, D. Juniper sprouts are a food source for mistletoe Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the origin of the Christmas tradition of hanging mistletoe in Britain? Options: A. It was brought to Britain by British colonists in the New World, B. It was a European tradition that was adopted in Britain, C. It was a British tradition that was adopted in Europe, D. It was a Scandinavian tradition that was adopted in Britain Correct Option: B
Question 8: What do the pearly berries on mistletoe represent? Options: A. They are a sign of the plant's magical qualities, B. They are a sign of the plant's fertility, C. They are a symbol of love, peace, and unity, representing the plant's ability to bring people together, D. They are a sign of the plant's ability to heal Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the significance of mistletoe in the myth of Baldur? Options: A. Mistletoe is a symbol of death in the myth of Baldur, B. Mistletoe is a symbol of love and fertility in the myth of Baldur, representing the transformation of the plant from a symbol of death to one of peace and love, C. Mistletoe is a symbol of Baldur's resurrection, D. Mistletoe has no connection to the myth of Baldur Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the significance of mistletoe in modern times? Options: A. It is a rare and endangered plant species, B. It is a highly invasive plant species, C. It is a keystone species that supports biodiversity and has cultural and symbolic significance, D. It has no significance in modern times Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The sight of mistletoe may either send
you scurrying or if you have your eye on someone, awaiting an opportunity
beneath its snow white berries. But how did the festive Christmas 
tradition of kissing under mistletoe come about? The long lived custom intertwines 
the mythology and biology of this intriguing plant. There are more than 1,000 species of
mistletoe which grows the world over. In fact, the ancient Europeans
were so captivated by the plant’s unusual growth habits 
that they included it in their legends and myths. In ancient Rome, Pliny the Elder 
described how the Druid priesthood in ancient England
believed that mistletoe was a plant dropped down from heaven 
by the gods; that explained its unlikely position 
amongst the high branches of certain trees. They also believed it had powers 
of healing and bestowing fertility. Meanwhile, Scandinavian legends told 
of the plant’s mystical qualities in the story of the god Baldur
and his adoring mother, Frigg, goddess of love, marriage and fertility. Frigg loved her son so much 
that she commanded every plant, animal and inanimate object to vow 
they’d never harm him. In her fervor, however, 
she overlooked the mistletoe. The mischievous god Loki realized 
this oversight, and pierced Baldur’s heart with an arrow 
carved from a mistletoe branch. Frigg cried tears of such
sadness that they formed the mistletoe’s pearly berries, making the other gods pity her 
and agree to resurrect Baldur. Hearing the news, Frigg became 
so overjoyed that she transformed the mistletoe from a symbol of death
into one of peace and love. She mandated a one day
truce for all fights and that everyone embraced beneath 
its branches when they passed to spread more love into the world. In the 17th century, British colonists 
arriving in the New World found a different but very similar looking
species of mistletoe. They applied it to these tales
of magic, fertility and love, spreading the mistletoe hanging tradition
from Europe into America. By the 18th century, people 
in Britain had turned this into a Christmas tradition. But this custom comes down to more 
than just human imagination. All of it was inspired
by the plant’s intriguing biology. We see mistletoe as a festive decoration,
but draped on tree boughs in the wild, it’s known as a partly parasitic plant. Mistletoe relies on modified roots
called haustoria that penetrate the tree bark 
and siphon off the water and minerals trees carry up their trunks. To colonize nearby trees with its seeds, mistletoe depends on birds 
and other creatures to do the dispersing. Birds that eat the mistletoe’s 
sticky white berries sometimes get rid of the gluey seeds
by wiping them off onto tree bark, or with a bit of luck, they excrete the indigestible seed
onto a tree where it germinates and starts to grow. With its resilience and foliage 
that stays lush even while the surrounding trees 
lose their leaves, you can see why mistletoe captivated
our superstitious ancestors. They saw these as signs of the plant’s
magical qualities and fertility. Even today, the mistletoe inspires wonder with the diversity of wildlife
it supports. More than just a parasite, 
it’s also known as a keystone species. It's eaten by a diversity of animals,
including deer, elk, squirrels, chipmunks, porcupines, robins, bluebirds, 
mourning doves, and the butterfly genus Delius. Some mistletoe species
produce dense bushes, which are excellent nesting locations
for a variety of birds. And despite their parasitic
relationship with trees, mistletoes can also help other plants. For instance, juniper sprouts 
near mistletoe to benefit from the visiting berry-eating birds. Through the many benefits it provides, mistletoe influences diversity 
and allows ecosystems to flourish. You might even say, 
that for this iconic plant, life imitates legend. In the wild, mistletoe has the power 
to bring things together. And in our own traditions 
we see that happening too.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The ancient British druids believed the mistletoe was dropped from heaven by:
Options: A. Birds, B. Angels, C. Astronauts, D. Gods
Correct Option: D

Question 1: What is the total number of digits on a typical human hand? Options: A. 6, B. 8, C. 10, D. 12 Correct Option: C
Question 2: How can you count up to 12 on just one hand? Options: A. By using the thumb as a pointer to indicate each section, B. By counting each finger individually, C. By using the other hand to keep track, D. By using a calculator Correct Option: None
Question 3: If you can count up to 12 on one hand, how can you count higher? Options: A. By using the other hand to keep track of each time you get to 12, B. By using the sections on the second hand to count 12 groups of 12, C. By using the other hand to mark groups of 12, D. By using a computer Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the advantage of using the sections on the second hand to count 12 groups of 12? Options: A. It allows you to count more precisely, B. It allows you to count faster, C. It allows you to count higher, D. It allows you to count in a different base Correct Option: A
Question 5: How can you represent the number 7 using just two options per finger? Options: A. By having 4+2+1 fingers raised, B. By having 3 fingers raised, C. By having 5 fingers raised, D. By having 4 fingers raised Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the maximum number you can represent using a base-three positional system with fingers that can be bent halfway? Options: A. 59,049, B. 59,048, C. 59,050, D. 59,051 Correct Option: B
Question 7: Why are computers based on the principle of base-two? Options: A. Because it is the most efficient way to represent numbers, B. Because it is the simplest way to represent numbers, C. Because it is the default way to represent numbers, D. Because it is the only way to represent numbers Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the advantage of using a base-two positional system in computers? Options: A. It allows them to perform billions of operations, B. It allows them to perform millions of operations, C. It allows them to perform thousands of operations, D. It allows them to perform hundreds of operations Correct Option: A
Question 9: How can you evaluate the efficiency of a counting system? Options: A. By comparing it to other counting systems, B. By comparing it to a calculator, C. By comparing it to a computer, D. By comparing it to a human brain Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the most important factor in determining the limit of how many different finger parts you can count with precision? Options: A. The number of fingers on your hand, B. The number of sections on each finger, C. The number of creases on each finger, D. Your own flexibility and ingenuity Correct Option: D
Question 11: How can you represent numbers using a base-two positional system? Options: A. By using a combination of powers of 10, B. By using a combination of powers of 2, C. By using a combination of powers of 3, D. By using a combination of powers of 4 Correct Option: B
Question 12: What is the maximum number you can represent using just two options per finger (up and down)? Options: A. 1023, B. 512, C. 2048, D. 4096 Correct Option: A
Question 13: What is the system of positional notation that allows for different magnitudes of value? Options: A. Base-ten system, B. Base-two system, C. Base-three system, D. Positional notation system Correct Option: D
Question 14: How can you use positional notation to represent numbers using fingers? Options: A. By using a combination of powers of 10, B. By using a combination of powers of 2, C. By using a combination of powers of 3, D. By using a combination of powers of 4 Correct Option: B
Question 15: What is the advantage of using positional notation with fingers? Options: A. It allows you to count more precisely, B. It allows you to count faster, C. It allows you to count higher, D. It allows you to count in a different base Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The sight of mistletoe may either send
you scurrying or if you have your eye on someone, awaiting an opportunity
beneath its snow white berries. But how did the festive Christmas 
tradition of kissing under mistletoe come about? The long lived custom intertwines 
the mythology and biology of this intriguing plant. There are more than 1,000 species of
mistletoe which grows the world over. In fact, the ancient Europeans
were so captivated by the plant’s unusual growth habits 
that they included it in their legends and myths. In ancient Rome, Pliny the Elder 
described how the Druid priesthood in ancient England
believed that mistletoe was a plant dropped down from heaven 
by the gods; that explained its unlikely position 
amongst the high branches of certain trees. They also believed it had powers 
of healing and bestowing fertility. Meanwhile, Scandinavian legends told 
of the plant’s mystical qualities in the story of the god Baldur
and his adoring mother, Frigg, goddess of love, marriage and fertility. Frigg loved her son so much 
that she commanded every plant, animal and inanimate object to vow 
they’d never harm him. In her fervor, however, 
she overlooked the mistletoe. The mischievous god Loki realized 
this oversight, and pierced Baldur’s heart with an arrow 
carved from a mistletoe branch. Frigg cried tears of such
sadness that they formed the mistletoe’s pearly berries, making the other gods pity her 
and agree to resurrect Baldur. Hearing the news, Frigg became 
so overjoyed that she transformed the mistletoe from a symbol of death
into one of peace and love. She mandated a one day
truce for all fights and that everyone embraced beneath 
its branches when they passed to spread more love into the world. In the 17th century, British colonists 
arriving in the New World found a different but very similar looking
species of mistletoe. They applied it to these tales
of magic, fertility and love, spreading the mistletoe hanging tradition
from Europe into America. By the 18th century, people 
in Britain had turned this into a Christmas tradition. But this custom comes down to more 
than just human imagination. All of it was inspired
by the plant’s intriguing biology. We see mistletoe as a festive decoration,
but draped on tree boughs in the wild, it’s known as a partly parasitic plant. Mistletoe relies on modified roots
called haustoria that penetrate the tree bark 
and siphon off the water and minerals trees carry up their trunks. To colonize nearby trees with its seeds, mistletoe depends on birds 
and other creatures to do the dispersing. Birds that eat the mistletoe’s 
sticky white berries sometimes get rid of the gluey seeds
by wiping them off onto tree bark, or with a bit of luck, they excrete the indigestible seed
onto a tree where it germinates and starts to grow. With its resilience and foliage 
that stays lush even while the surrounding trees 
lose their leaves, you can see why mistletoe captivated
our superstitious ancestors. They saw these as signs of the plant’s
magical qualities and fertility. Even today, the mistletoe inspires wonder with the diversity of wildlife
it supports. More than just a parasite, 
it’s also known as a keystone species. It's eaten by a diversity of animals,
including deer, elk, squirrels, chipmunks, porcupines, robins, bluebirds, 
mourning doves, and the butterfly genus Delius. Some mistletoe species
produce dense bushes, which are excellent nesting locations
for a variety of birds. And despite their parasitic
relationship with trees, mistletoes can also help other plants. For instance, juniper sprouts 
near mistletoe to benefit from the visiting berry-eating birds. Through the many benefits it provides, mistletoe influences diversity 
and allows ecosystems to flourish. You might even say, 
that for this iconic plant, life imitates legend. In the wild, mistletoe has the power 
to bring things together. And in our own traditions 
we see that happening too.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The mistletoe’s berries represent Frigga’s:
Options: A. Tears of joy, B. Tears of sadness, C. Fair skin, D. The whites of her eyes
Correct Option: B

you scurrying or if you have your eye on someone, awaiting an opportunity
beneath its snow white berries. But how did the festive Christmas

described how the Druid priesthood in ancient England
believed that mistletoe was a plant dropped down from heaven 
by the gods; that explained its unlikely position 
amongst the high branches of certain trees. They also believed it had powers 
of healing and bestowing fertility. Meanwhile, Scandinavian legends told 
of the plant’s mystical qualities in the story of the god Baldur
and his adoring mother, Frigg, goddess of love, marriage and fertility. Frigg loved her son so much 
that she commanded every plant, animal and inanimate object to vow 
they’d never harm him. In her fervor, however,

so overjoyed that she transformed the mistletoe from a symbol of death
into one of peace and love. She mandated a one day
truce for all fights and that everyone embraced beneath 
its branches when they passed to spread more love into the world. In the 17th century, British colonists 
arriving in the New World found a different but very similar looking
species of mistletoe. They applied it to these tales
of magic, fertility and love, spreading the mistletoe hanging tradition
from Europe into America. By the 18th century, people 
in Britain had turned this into a Christmas tradition. But this custom comes down to more 
than just human imagination. All of it was inspired
by the plant’s intriguing biology. We see mistletoe as a festive decoration,
but draped on tree boughs in the wild, it’s known as a partly parasitic plant. Mistletoe relies on modified roots
called haustoria that penetrate the tree bark 
and siphon off the water and minerals trees carry up their trunks. To colonize nearby trees with its seeds, mistletoe depends on birds 
and other creatures to do the dispersing. Birds that eat the mistletoe’s 
sticky white berries sometimes get rid of the gluey seeds
by wiping them off onto tree bark, or with a bit of luck, they excrete the indigestible seed
onto a tree where it germinates and starts to grow. With its resilience and foliage 
that stays lush even while the surrounding trees 
lose their leaves, you can see why mistletoe captivated
our superstitious ancestors. They saw these as signs of the plant’s
magical qualities and fertility. Even today, the mistletoe inspires wonder with the diversity of wildlife
it supports. More than just a parasite, 
it’s also known as a keystone species. It's eaten by a diversity of animals,
including deer, elk, squirrels, chipmunks, porcupines, robins, bluebirds, 
mourning doves, and the butterfly genus Delius. Some mistletoe species
produce dense bushes, which are excellent nesting locations

and allows ecosystems to flourish. You might even say, 
that for this iconic plant, life imitates legend. In the wild, mistletoe has the power 
to bring things together. And in our own traditions 
we see that happening too.

Question 11: How can you represent numbers using a base-two positional system? Options: A. By using a combination of powers of 10, B. By using a combination of powers of 2, C. By using a combination of powers of 3, D. By using a combination of powers of 4 Correct Option: B
Question 12: What is the maximum number you can represent using just two options per finger (up and down)? Options: A. 1023, B. 512, C. 2048, D. 4096 Correct Option: A
Question 13: What is the system of positional notation that allows for different magnitudes of value? Options: A. Base-ten system, B. Base-two system, C. Base-three system, D. Positional notation system Correct Option: D
Question 14: How can you use positional notation to represent numbers using fingers? Options: A. By using a combination of powers of 10, B. By using a combination of powers of 2, C. By using a combination of powers of 3, D. By using a combination of powers of 4 Correct Option: B
Question 15: What is the advantage of using positional notation with fingers? Options: A. It allows you to count more precisely, B. It allows you to count faster, C. It allows you to count higher, D. It allows you to count in a different base Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The sight of mistletoe may either send
you scurrying or if you have your eye on someone, awaiting an opportunity
beneath its snow white berries. But how did the festive Christmas 
tradition of kissing under mistletoe come about? The long lived custom intertwines 
the mythology and biology of this intriguing plant. There are more than 1,000 species of
mistletoe which grows the world over. In fact, the ancient Europeans
were so captivated by the plant’s unusual growth habits 
that they included it in their legends and myths. In ancient Rome, Pliny the Elder 
described how the Druid priesthood in ancient England
believed that mistletoe was a plant dropped down from heaven 
by the gods; that explained its unlikely position 
amongst the high branches of certain trees. They also believed it had powers 
of healing and bestowing fertility. Meanwhile, Scandinavian legends told 
of the plant’s mystical qualities in the story of the god Baldur
and his adoring mother, Frigg, goddess of love, marriage and fertility. Frigg loved her son so much 
that she commanded every plant, animal and inanimate object to vow 
they’d never harm him. In her fervor, however, 
she overlooked the mistletoe. The mischievous god Loki realized 
this oversight, and pierced Baldur’s heart with an arrow 
carved from a mistletoe branch. Frigg cried tears of such
sadness that they formed the mistletoe’s pearly berries, making the other gods pity her 
and agree to resurrect Baldur. Hearing the news, Frigg became 
so overjoyed that she transformed the mistletoe from a symbol of death
into one of peace and love. She mandated a one day
truce for all fights and that everyone embraced beneath 
its branches when they passed to spread more love into the world. In the 17th century, British colonists 
arriving in the New World found a different but very similar looking
species of mistletoe. They applied it to these tales
of magic, fertility and love, spreading the mistletoe hanging tradition
from Europe into America. By the 18th century, people 
in Britain had turned this into a Christmas tradition. But this custom comes down to more 
than just human imagination. All of it was inspired
by the plant’s intriguing biology. We see mistletoe as a festive decoration,
but draped on tree boughs in the wild, it’s known as a partly parasitic plant. Mistletoe relies on modified roots
called haustoria that penetrate the tree bark 
and siphon off the water and minerals trees carry up their trunks. To colonize nearby trees with its seeds, mistletoe depends on birds 
and other creatures to do the dispersing. Birds that eat the mistletoe’s 
sticky white berries sometimes get rid of the gluey seeds
by wiping them off onto tree bark, or with a bit of luck, they excrete the indigestible seed
onto a tree where it germinates and starts to grow. With its resilience and foliage 
that stays lush even while the surrounding trees 
lose their leaves, you can see why mistletoe captivated
our superstitious ancestors. They saw these as signs of the plant’s
magical qualities and fertility. Even today, the mistletoe inspires wonder with the diversity of wildlife
it supports. More than just a parasite, 
it’s also known as a keystone species. It's eaten by a diversity of animals,
including deer, elk, squirrels, chipmunks, porcupines, robins, bluebirds, 
mourning doves, and the butterfly genus Delius. Some mistletoe species
produce dense bushes, which are excellent nesting locations
for a variety of birds. And despite their parasitic
relationship with trees, mistletoes can also help other plants. For instance, juniper sprouts 
near mistletoe to benefit from the visiting berry-eating birds. Through the many benefits it provides, mistletoe influences diversity 
and allows ecosystems to flourish. You might even say, 
that for this iconic plant, life imitates legend. In the wild, mistletoe has the power 
to bring things together. And in our own traditions 
we see that happening too.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The mistletoe’s modified roots are called:
Options: A. Gills, B. Rhizome, C. Haustoria, D. Rhapsody
Correct Option: C

Because it is the default way to represent numbers, D. Because it is the only way to represent numbers Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the advantage of using a base-two positional system in computers? Options: A. It allows them to perform billions of operations, B. Question 9: How can you evaluate the efficiency of a counting system? Options: A. By comparing it to other counting systems, B. By comparing it to a calculator, C. By comparing it to a computer, D. By comparing it to a human brain Correct Option: A
